subject: Re: Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit in a big project, please?

messageBody:
Just FYI for the people on this list, I also recieved another helpful
reply by direct email from a list member.


Assuming a wish for privacy, I won't list the person's name, but
their reply follows :
=================================================================
I don't think you are necessarily missing something.

My interpretation of your problem is that you're abusing unit testing
while you should be doing less unit testing and more functional
testing.

Reduce the number of mocks, start working with your real objects.
This should decrease the test code considerably and reduce the
potential for errors (maintaining mock hierarchies can be very
expensive). I usually recommend to *not* use mocks until you
actually hit a barrier ( e.g. your tests take way too long). Even
so, tests that take a long time to run are okay in my book if what
you are testing actually takes a long time.

Also, have you taken a look at TestNG? ( http://testng.org)

It's more geared to functional testing than JUnit is and it might cut
down on your code as well, thanks to features such as DataProviders
(data-driven testing) and dependent methods...

Let me know if you have any questions.
=================================================================


I replied like this :
=================================================================
You make some interesting points - maybe the idea of less unit
testing and more functional testing is it... I can see the point of
unit testing, but it does seem to be an awful lot of work for not
much return.

I know what you mean about the mocks, but in order to make some of
our objects, you need to have a pile of other objects, and other
objects to make those, and so on, and it kind of piles up!
Also, isn't the point of the tests mainly to assert what methods are
called on what other objects, which you can only do with mocks?
And how could I test the result of those objects misbehaving, ie that
the exception I expect is thrown from the service when the DAO fails
to write and throws an exception? That's not something I could make
happen with a mock. And actually, I don't suppose I should try, or
it'll go & try to write to a database, won't it?
Or have I misunderstood or been misled here?

I haven't heard of TestNG - I'll take a peek...
=================================================================

Maybe this is also helpful to someone else out there, or at least
mildly interesting! :)

Cheers,
Tracey
